title: Should we sign a stipulation to judgement and allow an abstract to be placed on my home.
question: We were served with a suit on 5/26 by a collection agency for an old hospital bill that should have been reduced by a class action suit. The collection agency called us yesterday after reviewing the class action discounts and agreed to a settlement amount. Because we cannot pay the settlement amount in full, they agreed to a somewhat higher amount and said they will not dismiss the suit, but will send us a stipulation to judgement to sign and will then place an abstract on our home which will protect their interest if we sell the home or take a loan on it. The stipulation for judgement agrees to a monthly payment that we will review after six months. Is this a smart thing to sign rather than filing an answer for ourselves? Can we still include it if we decide to file bankruptcy later?
answers:
My advise is to have an experienced lawyer review the documents. A Stipulation for Judgment is an agreement which is not filed with the Court unless you default on a settlement agreement. Because they are telling you they plan to immediately put an abstract of judgment on your house my impression is that they are talking about a "Confession of Judgment" which is an immediate judgment against you and your spouse. They may be attempting to get you to sign a "Confession of Judgment" but calling it a "Stipulation for Judgment".

Robert M. Berger has been a practicing California attorney in the Los Angeles area for over 20 years focusing on the areas of estate planning, and business, real estate, construction law. Please contact him at (818) 606-1491 or by email at rmberger61@sbcglobal.net
Absolutely do not sign a stip for judgment. If anything sign a stipulation for judgment upon a default in your payments. This is a subtle but very important difference.

Your question does not include any specific dollar amounts, so I cannot tell you whether, in your specific case, the dollar amount is reasonable. However, in my experience, such settlements proposed to an unrepresented or unsophisticated consumer are usually quite unfair.

Because the bill is old, the Statute of Limitations may protect you from having a judgment entered. More facts are necessary to review this issue. Do not do anything that will cause the Statute of Limitations to re-start.

Usually, debt buyers do not get very much documentation from the original creditor. Medical debts are usually determined as being the "reasonable value" of the services provided.
If you are sued on such a medical bill, the collection agency must prove, with properly authenticated documents and witness testimony, the "reasonable value" of the services provided.

I advise. Do not sign anything from the collection agency. Sit down with an attorney for a half hour and review your case.

It is very difficult (if not impossible) to give you specific advice on the public forum. Generally speaking, it is better to settle than to litigate. However, when you stipulate to a judgment, the judgment is going to have adverse impact on your credit score. You really ought to have an attorney review the facts of your case, including the settled class action and the allegations of the collection agency's complaint, before deciding whether or not you will stipulate to a judgment.

Yes, unless the debt obligation resulted from fraud, a bankruptcy can discharge such debt.

I think Mr. Stempler gives some very good advice. I would add that you and your spouse should file a "homestead" on you property prior to any lien to protect a portion of the equity you may have in your principal residence.

On the videos on my website home page, I explain that there are plenty of other options to consider, before agreeing to have a judgment in your name and an abstract of judgment against you home and other property. Perhaps the class action settlement has a slight impact on your case. Have you considered consulting an experienced debt collection defense attorney to defend this lawsuit, if the plaintiff/collection agency refuses to negotiate on terms that you feel are acceptable? I think you should do more research before you agree to risk the equity in your home.
